freedomTour.tourTagline: 10 Plagues. 10 Stops. One Epic Journey to Freedom.

confrontationMoments.name: Who Is The Lord?
confrontationMoments.scene: The first confrontation - Moses demands freedom, Pharaoh mocks the God of Israel
confrontationMoments.mosesAction: Standing boldly with staff, speaking for God
confrontationMoments.pharaohAction: Seated on throne, dismissive and arrogant

confrontationMoments.name: Let My People Go
confrontationMoments.scene: The repeated demand that echoes through history

confrontationMoments.name: Hardened Heart
confrontationMoments.scene: Pharaoh doubles down after each plague

confrontationMoments.name: Rise and Go
confrontationMoments.scene: The final night - Pharaoh broken, commanding Israel to leave
confrontationMoments.mosesAction: Leading the people out at midnight

rivalryResearch.relationship: Moses, the humble shepherd called by God at the burning bush, versus Pharaoh, the god-king of Egypt who enslaved Israel. Their confrontation over the ten plagues is the ultimate clash of divine authority against human arrogance. Each plague answered one of Egypt's gods; each refusal hardened Pharaoh's heart until the final, devastating plague broke him.

keyMoments.title: First Confrontation
keyMoments.description: Moses and Aaron before Pharaoh's throne. 'Who is the LORD that I should heed Him?' The battle lines are drawn.

keyMoments.title: Staff to Serpent
keyMoments.description: Moses' staff becomes a serpent, swallowing Pharaoh's magicians' snakes. The first sign of whose power is greater.

keyMoments.title: Ten Plagues
keyMoments.description: Blood, frogs, lice, beasts, pestilence, boils, hail, locusts, darkness, death of firstborn. Each escalating, each giving Pharaoh a chance to relent.

keyMoments.title: The Hardened Heart
keyMoments.description: After each plague, Pharaoh's heart hardened. Sometimes he hardened it himself; sometimes God hardened it. The debate on free will echoes through millennia.

keyMoments.title: Death of Firstborn
keyMoments.description: At midnight, the final plague. Pharaoh rises in the night, his son dead, and finally releases Israel. 'Rise up, go out from among my people!'

keyMoments.title: The Pursuit
keyMoments.description: Even after releasing them, Pharaoh changes his mind and pursues Israel to the Red Sea. His final, fatal mistake.

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Moses standing before the throne, staff in hand, speaking God's command with humble authority. The shepherd who became prophet.
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Pharaoh seated in full regalia, dismissive wave, 'Who is the LORD?' The god-king meeting the God of slaves.
rivalryScenes.scene: Egyptian throne room, golden and imposing. Two powers meeting - divine versus earthly.
rivalryScenes.energy: Clash of authorities, humble power vs arrogant pride

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Moses with staff raised, calling down divine judgment. Face showing sorrow at the necessity, but unwavering resolve.
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Pharaoh surrounded by plague effects, still defiant, heart hardening even as his kingdom crumbles.
rivalryScenes.scene: Egypt in chaos from the current plague. Moses as channel of power, Pharaoh as stubborn obstacle.

rivalryScenes.heroAction: Moses leading Israel out at midnight, the blood on the doorposts behind them, freedom finally achieved.
rivalryScenes.villainAction: Pharaoh broken, grief-stricken over his dead son, commanding Israel to leave with hollow voice.
rivalryScenes.scene: The night of the Exodus. Death has passed over Israel but struck Egypt. The tyrant is broken.
rivalryScenes.energy: Victory through suffering, freedom at terrible cost

scriptureReferences.english: Who is the LORD that I should heed Him?
Rise up, go out from among my people!

scriptureReferences.hebrew: וַיֵּט מֹשֶׁה אֶת יָדוֹ עַל הַיָּם
scriptureReferences.english: Moses stretched out his hand over the sea

player.name: Moses
player.attributeDescription: the staff that became a serpent, struck the Nile, and parted the sea
player.visualStyle: the prophet who confronted the mightiest empire on earth with nothing but a wooden staff and God's word
player.clothing: simple shepherd's robes, humble garments contrasting with the Egyptian opulence around him
player.physicalDescription: elderly man with long white beard, penetrating eyes that have seen the burning bush, weathered skin from decades in the wilderness, staff always in hand
player.archetype: The Prophet — spoke for God, wielded divine power through humility

figure.name: Pharaoh
figure.attributeDescription: the royal crook and flail of Egyptian kingship, symbols of his divine authority
figure.visualStyle: the god-king of Egypt, supreme ruler, master of the greatest empire
figure.clothing: full Egyptian royal regalia: double crown (pschent), golden collar, pleated linen, jeweled armbands, royal crook and flail
figure.physicalDescription: regal bearing, sharp features, kohl-lined eyes, clean-shaven or ceremonial beard, expression of absolute authority and growing desperation as plagues progress
figure.archetype: The Tyrant — worldly power that cannot withstand divine authority

connection: The ultimate confrontation: humble prophet vs god-king, divine authority vs earthly power
